entry.title: How I Escaped Browser Tab Hell: A Lesson in Choosing the Right AI Tool
entry.content:
The Journey

The Problem: 10 Years of Digital Hoarding

After a decade at SAP, I was drowning in resources. My solution? Browser bookmarks that grew into an unmanageable mess. When Chrome introduced Tab Groups, I thought I'd found salvation‚Äîuntil I realized I was maintaining 200+ tabs across multiple groups. The anxiety from my digital FOMO was worse than ever.

Back to Basics (With a Twist)

I returned to curated bookmarks but with a new goal: create a "PM Toolbox" that I could easily maintain *and* share with colleagues across the organization. I built a clean bookmark folder and mirrored it on a wiki page.

The Maintenance Nightmare

Within weeks, reality hit: my bookmark folder evolved constantly, requiring manual wiki updates. Chrome's bookmark export format (the ancient Netscape standard) made extracting subsets error-prone and frustrating. I needed automation.

First Attempt: GenAI Fails the Coding Test

I tried using Claude 4.5 Sonnet through GenAI-XL. Despite multiple attempts, it couldn't handle Chrome's non-standard HTML format. It kept reaching for HTML parsing libraries that failed, then suggested an obscure Netscape parser that violated SAP standards. Dead end.

Second Attempt: GitHub Copilot Nails It

The next day, I switched to VSCode with GitHub Copilot. Here's what changed:
  1. I wrote clear requirements in a `.github/copilot-instructions.md` file, specifically calling out the Netscape format complexity
  2. Copilot enhanced my requirements, suggesting testing coverage and documentation guidelines (80% of the final instructions came from Copilot)
  3. I switched to Agent mode and prompted: *"Please create the missing files. Do not reference public code in your response."* (Critical for enterprise compliance)
The result? A complete, working script‚Äîinstantly.

But it got better. When I asked for a second script to generate Confluence tables, Copilot:
  • Created the implementation
  • Built the test suite when I requested it
  • Ran the tests autonomously, discovered bugs, and fixed them‚Äîall without me asking
I was genuinely amazed.

Key Takeaways

1. Match the Tool to the Task

  • General AI (like Claude): Excellent for brainstorming, requirements refinement, and PM tasks
  • Specialized coding AI (like GitHub Copilot): Purpose-built for implementation and testing

2. Clear Requirements Are Non-Negotiable

Both attempts used AI, but only the second succeeded because I provided structured, detailed requirements upfront.

3. Embrace Test-Driven Development

Even with AI assistance, automated testing is essential. Copilot's self-correction only worked because tests exposed the bugs immediately.

4. Simple Solutions Often Win

Sometimes the answer isn't a shinier tool‚Äîit's going back to basics (curated bookmarks) with smart automation layered on top.

The Bottom Line

AI coding assistants aren't magic‚Äîthey're power tools. Like any tool, they require the right context, clear instructions, and quality controls. When you provide those, the results can be transformative.

For PMs and non-developers: you don't need to be a coder to automate your work. You just need to understand your requirements so you can clearly write them down and choose the AI tool designed for the job.

References

You can find the scripts in question here

entry.title: Winter Wonderland - 3 Projects for the Winter and Holiday Season
entry.content:
Here you‚Äôll find three winter and holiday themed projects for beginners and more advanced learners.
The resources are suitable for workshops in informal learning settings or for independent study periods.

The videos are step by step tutorials that show you how to build the projects. Especially the digital greeting card and the snowflake generator, can then be customized individually.

 

Introduction to Snap! and saving projects

If this is your first time programming with Snap!, take a look at this introductory video: 
https://youtu.be/cbRQ7nGqWLo?si=WSEAK6xuYk3HfAeR 

There you‚Äôll get an overview of how to program with Snap! and how to save your projects and share them with others.

Saving and sharing are also explained in more detail on this activity card:
https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/FY7NHCt?rc=10&doi=SAP1261708 

 

Project 1: Writing Home for Christmas - Create your Digital Greeting Card

The first project is well suited for Snap! beginners. Using animations and graphic effects, you will build a digital interactive greeting card.

The examples use Christmas-themed winter motives, but if your Christmas isn't in winter or you're celebrating other holidays, feel free to adjust the project accordingly. 

Result of a digital greeting card: Alonzo jumps when he is clicked. A yeti changes its costume several times when it is entered by the mouse pointer. When the space bar is pressed, ‚ÄúMerry Christmas‚Äù is written on the stage in a random color. In the background you can see a snowy landscape and a Christmas tree.Result of another digital greeting card: A sprig of holly jumps when clicked. The yeti changes costumes, adjusts its size, and applies a graphic effect when it is clicked. The snowflake spins and gets smaller when clicked. Above it, ‚ÄúMerry Christmas‚Äù is written. In the background you can see a snowy landscape.

Follow the video tutorial to create your own digital greeting card:
https://youtu.be/cbRQ7nGqWLo?si=k_W5D3fZ5PFwZBhf&t=691 

Read the activity cards (pages 3 to 6) to understand the individual ideas shown in the video (animation through multiple costumes, animation through multiple movements, playing sounds, adding backgrounds): 
https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/FY7NHCt?rc=10&doi=SAP1261708

Take a look at the solution project from the video tutorial:
https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Project%20Winterwonderland 

 

Project 2: Let It Snow! - Build an Interactive Snow Globe

In this project, an interactive digital snow globe is created using clones of a snowflake sprite. The swarm of snowflakes can be controlled via the microphone volume or the tilt sensors of a mobile device.

Result of the snow globe project

The snowflakes are clones that follow a lead flake, which moves forward at a certain speed and bounces off the edge. This speed slightly decreases after each movement. A loud noise (microphone volume > 50), such as blowing into the microphone, resets the speed to its maximum value.

In this video, the project is built step by step so you can code along:
https://youtu.be/cbRQ7nGqWLo?si=DoYeP45clUr3rwj1&t=1869 

These activity cards contain the individual steps for review (starting on page 7):
https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/FY7NHCt?rc=10&doi=SAP1261708 

 

Control via a mobile device

In addition to the microphone, the speed can also be controlled using the tilt sensors of a smartphone or tablet.
To access these sensors, the "Mobile Device Sensors" library must be loaded first. It contains only one block, which provides access to the tilt sensors. The x and y tilts correspond to the axes on the Snap! stage ‚Äî that is, the x component measures the tilt to the left and right, and the y component measures the forward and backward tilt. The tilt block (right) can be loaded via the file menu ‚Üí Libraries (left). It can be found in the "Mobile Device Sensors" library.

Instead of resetting the "wind" variable based on the microphone volume to speed the snowflakes up again, you can also use the tilt of a phone or tablet. The following script sets ‚Äúwind‚Äù to 30 whenever the device is tilted more than 45¬∞ to the left or right (which corresponds to a tilt of more than 50 or less than ‚Äì50 in the x-direction).

This script shows how the "wind" variable can be reset via the tilt of a mobile device.

This way you can control the snowflakes with your mobile phone: 
The snow globe is activated with a right tilt of the phone.

This solution project contains the code for controlling the snow globe via the microphone and the tilt sensor of mobile devices:
https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=SnowGlobe-EN 

 

Project 3: Snowflake Designer

In this project, the cut from block in Snap! is literally the star of the show. It allows us to cut triangles in such a way that, when stamped and mirrored multiple times, they create these beautiful, star-shaped snowflakes.

5 snowflakes which were created using the Snowflake Designer. The first three snowflakes have a hexagon as their basic shape, the forth one is created from a square, the last on from a decagon.

This video tutorial guides you through the programming process for the Snowflake Designer step by step: 
https://youtu.be/zIMTxhrpkKQ?si=Klw0U9f57sZU3Zp8 

With this solution project you can check your results or test the program:
https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Snowflake-Designer-EN 

The solution project is a generalized version of the Snowflake Designer. Here, the generated triangle can be adjusted using the ‚Äúpoints‚Äù variable so that, after unfolding, a polygon with the corresponding number of vertices is created.

To do this, the code must be adapted in the following places:

In the paper object, the distance covered with the "move" block after turning the sprite depends on the number stored in the ‚Äúpoints‚Äù variable. Accordingly, the other angles of the triangle adjust automatically:
Three triangles drawn depending on the ‚Äúpoints‚Äù variable. The input to the tan of block is (360¬∞ / points) / 2.

If the triangle has different dimensions, the number of repetitions and the rotation angle must also be adjusted in the script that ‚Äúunfolds‚Äù the triangle to form the polygon. The number of repeats equals the desired number of points, and the rotation angle is 360¬∞ / points.

On the left, you can see the script for ‚Äúunfolding‚Äù the triangle. The number of repeats and the rotation angle are defined based on the ‚Äúpoints‚Äù variable. On the right, you can see the results of this script ‚Äî the resulting polygons when ‚Äúpoints‚Äù is set to 4 or 6.

 

Have fun trying the projects ‚ù§Ô∏èüéÑ‚ùÑÔ∏èüåü

entry.title: Re: Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
entry.content:
Hi,
currently we have just the samples in the portal. The one in the custom page overview:
https://ui5.sap.com/test-resources/sap/fe/core/fpmExplorer/index.html#/topic/customPage
and the one in the custom draft handling:
https://ui5.sap.com/test-resources/sap/fe/core/fpmExplorer/index.html#/controllerExtensions/customEditFlow

We aim for more full samples in the future.

If the create button is missing next to the table it's either due to the fact the UI is not in edit mode (ui>/isEditable is set to true, in case you have a custom logic you might need to set it) or your entity set is not insertable.

Best regards,
Marcel

entry.title: Digitale Feiertage mit Snap! - 3 Projektideen zum Winter-Wunderland
entry.content:
Hier findest du 3 Projekte zur kalten Jahreszeit f√ºr Einsteiger:innen und Fortgeschrittene. 
Die Materialien eignen sich f√ºr Workshops im informellen Bildungskontext oder Freiarbeitsstunden.

Die Videos erkl√§ren Schritt f√ºr Schritt, wie die Projekte gebaut werden. Besonders die Digitale Gru√ükarte und der Schneeflocken-Generator k√∂nnen dann individualisiert werden. 

 

Einf√ºhrung in Snap! und Abspeichern von Projekten

Ist das dein erstes Mal Programmieren mit Snap!, wirf doch einen Blick auf dieses Einf√ºhrungsvideo:
 https://youtu.be/ZCSQ5ycSHLY?si=swKL6o3W_HjaJDzf 

Dort erh√§ltst du einen √úberblick dar√ºber, wie du mit Snap! programmieren kannst und wie du deine Projekte abspeichern und mit anderen teilen kannst. 

Das Abspeichern und Teilen wird auf dieser Lernkarte noch einmal genau erkl√§rt: 
https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/qk2gW6X?rc=10&doi=SAP1260370 

 

Projekt 1: In der Weihnachtspoststelle - Erstelle eine Digitale Gru√ükarte

Das erste Projekt eignet sich gut f√ºr Einsteiger:innen in Snap!. Es werden mithilfe von Grafikeffekten und einfachen Animationen digitale, interaktive Gru√ükarten erzeugt. 

In den Karten nutzen wir Weihnachts- und Wintermotive. Solltest du Weihnachten nicht feiern oder eine Gru√ükarte f√ºr einen anderen Anlass ben√∂tigen, kannst du nat√ºrlich thematisch passende Hintergr√ºnde und Animationsideen daf√ºr √ºberlegen. 

Ergebnis einer digitalen Gru√ükarte. Alonzo springt, wenn er angeklickt wird. Ein Yeti wechselt das Kost√ºm mehrmals, wenn er vom Mauszeiger betreten wird. Beim Dr√ºcken der Leertaste wird "Frohe Weihnachten" in einer zuf√§lligen Farbe auf die B√ºhne geschrieben. Im Hintergrund ist eine Schneelandschaft und eine Tannenbaum zu sehen.Ergebnis einer weiteren digitalen Gru√ükarte. Ein Stechpalmenzweig springt, wenn angeklickt. Der Yeti wechselt die Kost√ºme, √§ndert seine Gr√∂√üe und wendet einen Grafikeffekt an. Die Schneeflocke dreht sich und wird kleiner, wenn sie angeklickt wird. Dar√ºber steht "Merry Christmas" geschrieben. Im Hintergrund ist eine Schneelandschaft zu sehen.

Folge der Videoanleitung, um eine eigene Digitale Gru√ükarte zu gestalten: 
https://youtu.be/ZCSQ5ycSHLY?si=w8Qd4tFtYYoY_rDe&t=880 

Lies die Lernkarte, um die einzelnen Ideen nachzuvollziehen (Animation durch mehrere Kost√ºme, Animation durch mehrere Bewegungen, Kl√§nge abspielen, Hintergr√ºnde einf√ºgen):
https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/wpzxHPq?rc=10&doi=SAP1260223  

Wirf einen Blick auf das L√∂sungsprojekt aus der Video-Anleitung: 
https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Projekt%20Weihnachtspoststelle&editMode&noRun 

 

Projekt 2: Schneefl√∂ckchen Wei√ür√∂ckchen - Erstelle eine interaktive Schneekugel

In diesem Projekt wird mithilfe von Klonen eine interaktive digitale Schneekugel erzeugt, die √ºber die Lautst√§rke des Mikrofons oder die Neigungssensoren eines Mobilger√§ts gesteuert werden kann. 

Ergebnis des Schneekugel-Projekts

Die Schneeflocken sind Klone, die der Leitflocke folgen, die sich in einer bestimmten Geschwindigkeit vorw√§rts bewegt und vom Rand abprallt. Diese Geschwindigkeit wird nach jeder Bewegung ein wenig kleiner. Durch ein lautes Ger√§usch (Mikrofon-Lautst√§rke > 50) wie z.B. Blasen in das Mikrofon wird die Geschwindigkeit wieder auf den Maximalwert zur√ºckgesetzt. 

In diesem Video wird das Projekt St√ºck f√ºr St√ºck zum Mitprogrammieren gebaut: 
https://youtu.be/ZCSQ5ycSHLY?si=p7yyYHbhC6TotCI7&t=2186 

Auf diesen Lernkarten sind die einzelnen Schritte zum Nachlesen zu finden (ab Seite 7): 
https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/wpzxHPq?rc=10&doi=SAP1260223 

 

Steuerung √ºber ein Mobilger√§t

Neben dem Mikrofon kann die Geschwindigkeit z.B. auch √ºber die Neigungssensoren eines Smartphones oder Tablets gesteuert werden. 
Um auf diese zugreifen zu k√∂nnen, muss zuerst das "Mobile Device Sensors" Modul geladen werden. Darin ist nur ein Block enthalten, der Zugriff auf die Neigungssensoren gibt. Die x- und y-Neigungen entsprechen den Achsen auf der Snap!-B√ºhne, d.h. die x-Komponente misst die Neigung nach links und rechts, die y-Komponente die Neigung nach vorn und hinten. 

Der Neigung-Block (rechts) kann √ºber das Dateimen√º -> Module (links) geladen werden. Er befindet sich im "Mobile Device Sensors" Modul.

Statt die Variable aufgrund der Lautst√§rke des Mikrofons zur√ºckzusetzen und die Schneeflocken dadurch wieder zu beschleunigen, kann auch die Neigung des Handys oder Tablets verwendet werden. Das folgende Skript setzt "Wind" auf 30, immer wenn das Handy mehr als 45¬∞ nach links oder rechts geneigt wird (das entspricht einer Neigung von mehr als 50 bzw. weniger als -50 in x-Richtung). 

Dieses Skript zeigt an, wie man die "Wind"-Variable √ºber die Neigung eines Mobilger√§ts zur√ºcksetzen kann.

Dadurch kann das Projekt z.B. √ºber das Handy gesteuert werden:

Schneekugel wird √ºber die Neigung des Handys nach rechts aktiviert.

Dieses L√∂sungsprojekt enth√§lt den gesamten Code f√ºr die Steuerung mit dem Mikrofon und dem Neigungssensor von Mobilger√§ten:
https://snap.berkeley.edu/project?username=jadga&projectname=Schneekugel%2dDE 

 

Projekt 3: Schneeflocken-Designer

In diesem Projekt ist der schneide aus Block von Snap! im wahrsten Sinne des Wortes der Star. Er l√§sst uns Dreiecke so zurechtschneiden, dass sie mehrmals gestempelt und gespiegelt diese sternf√∂rmigen, sch√∂nen Schneeflocken erzeugen k√∂nnen.

5 Schneeflocken, die mit dem Schneeflocken-Designer erzeugt wurden. Die ersten 3 Schneeflocken haben ein Sechseck als Grundlage, die vierte ein Viereck, die letzte ein Zehneck.

In der Videoanleitung kannst du Schritt f√ºr Schritt die Programmierung des Schneeflocken-Designers nachvollziehen: 
https://youtu.be/HMqelYdkhWE?si=TPyaGubN5ENzD-r6 

Im L√∂sungsprojekt kannst du dein Projekt √ºberpr√ºfen und das Programm testen:
https://snap.berkeley.edu/project?username=jadga&projectname=Schneeflocken%2dDesigner%2dDE 

Das L√∂sungsprojekt ist eine generalisierte Form des Schneeflocken-Designers. Dort kann √ºber die Variable "Zacken" das erzeugte Dreieck so angepasst werden, dass nach dem Entfalten ein Polygon mit entsprechender Eckenzahl entsteht. 
Daf√ºr muss der Code an folgenden Stellen angepasst werden: 

Im Papierobjekt ist die Strecke, die nach dem Drehen mit dem "gehe" Block zur√ºckgelegt wird, abh√§ngig von der Zahl, die in der "Zacken" Variable abgespeichert ist. Je nachdem, ver√§ndern sich die anderen Winkel des Dreiecks automatisch mit:

Drei Dreiecke, die in Abh√§ngigkeit der Variable Zacken gezeichnet wurden. Die Eingabe in den "tan von" Block ist (360¬∞ / Zacken) / 2

Hat das Dreieck andere Dimensionen, m√ºssen auch die Anzahl an Wiederholungen und der Drehwinkel angepasst werden im Skript, das das Dreieck "entfaltet", damit das Vieleck entsteht. Die Wiederholung ist die Anzahl der gew√ºnschten Zacken, der Drehwinkel ist 360¬∞/ Zacken:

Links ist das Skript f√ºr die "Entfaltung" des Dreiecks zu sehen. Wiederholung und Drehwinkel sind in Abh√§ngigkeit der "Zacken"-Variable beschrieben. Rechts sieht man die Ergebnisse dieses Skripts, die entstehenden Vielecke, wenn Zacken auf 4 oder 6 gesetzt wird.

 

Viel Spa√ü beim Ausprobieren ‚ù§Ô∏èüéÑ‚ùÑÔ∏èüåü

entry.title: Re: Smarter Built-In Support in C4C: A Unified and Upgraded Experience
entry.content:
Hi john,

It should work for any cloud product except Concur

2518600 - How does a customer invite partner S-user IDs to create cases on their behalf using the Service Partner User functionality - SAP for Me - SAP for Me

The customer first invites the partner, then the partner accepts, then (a step often omitted) the customer sets a validity on the invitation, then assigns authorizations

(customer must be cloud admin)

So it is likely an issue with missing validity date  or missing authorization.

You can reach out to CIC if this still does not work and create a case for SAP for Me (XX-SER-FORME), they will assist.

entry.title: Re: Unable to update Journal Entry Line with KOART value "D"
entry.content:
Hello @JastinC1 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/6350d7531a4d424de10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US

The public cloud does not allow updating the Reference1ByBusinessPartner field on journal entry lines with KOART=D because changes to customer lines are restricted. Instead, you should reverse the original document and repost a corrected entry. These restrictions are to enforce compliance in the audit framework.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Processing of Purchase Requisition
entry.content:
Dear @Matt42,

What you are seeing is standard behavior in Public Cloud:

  • My Purchase Requisitions New intentionally allows users to edit PRs even after a follow-on document exists (PO created). SAP explicitly calls this a new feature of the new SSP app

More detail below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3498391

 

  • PR->PO conversion is not designed as 1:1. SAP own training material states that you may create one or several POs, depending on supplier / purchasing org / purchasing group, etc.

 

Answer 1. Best practice control (no hard lock)

  • Use in CBC: Manage Conditions to Restart Flexible Workflow
  • For more complex rules (by plant, company code, etc.), use Badi MM_PUR_S4_PR_WFL_RESTART (Define of Conditions to Restart Flexible Workflow in Purchase Requisitions)

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2775709

Hard lock, what you asked for, block edits once release is completed

SAP workaround recommendation is:

  • Implement Badi MM_PUR_S4_PR_MODIFY_ITEM
  • Read the original approval/release status from I_PurchaseRequisitionItemAPI01, field PurReqnReleaseStatus
  • If it‚Äôs already release completed, raise an error message and stop the change
  • You should check PurReqnReleaseStatus status, not FRGKZ/FRGST

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3498391

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/a25472838bd846e3992586e16c230794.html

Answer 2. Not allow another PO from same PR

There are two different problems that can often mix:

  1. Header status is aggregated that can mean some items have follow-on docs, other items may still be legitimately convertible hence SAP allows creating another PO
  2. Even for the same item, SAP can still allow another PO if there‚Äôs still open quantity/value (partial ordering) or if your process allows splitting.

For point 1. SAP provides a direct workaround:

  • Implement Badi MM_PUR_S4_PR_CHECK
  • Check field PROCESSINGSTATUS, if it indicates follow-on exists, raise an error

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3498391

For point 2. Enforce only one PO per PR

There is no standard customizing switch to force 1:1, but you can enforce it with a PO check Badi:

  • Implement Badi BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO and reject saving if the referenced PR already has a different PO.

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3544706

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Implementation and Customizing of Real-Time Instant P...
entry.content:
To enable Instant Payments in SAP ERP 6.0, you will primarily need to configure the Payment Medium Workbench (PMW) for specific instant payment formats, potentially integrate with SAP Bank Communication Management (BCM) or SAP Payment Engine, and refer to SAP Notes like: SAP Notes 2530182  and SAP Notes 2386927 

which provide foundational guidance on SEPA Instant Credit Transfer, though mainly focused on S/4HANA.
 
If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks, Denis

entry.content:

For anybody facing the same issue, this is how I did it.

entry.title: Failed to post Physical Inventory Document due to unknown reconciliation issue Code: M7059
entry.content:
We are trying to post Physical Inventory Document which failed. We have checked Account Auto-Determination, and make sure that GBB is assigned to account DIGITS.

Diagnosis

No direct postings can be made to the G/L account (because it is a reconciliation account).

System Response

The system cannot post the amount to this account.

Procedure

If the system has determined the G/L account, the system setting is faulty. Contact your systems administrator.

If you have entered the G/L account manually, enter a different account or cancel the account entered, so that the system determines an account automatically.

Message no. M7059

 

When we view account in app Manage G/L Account Master we cannot see assignment to reconciliation account. 

 

 

 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Failed to post Physical Inventory Document due to unk...
entry.content:
You can use App Display G/L Account changes  to see changes on account. You can see if account Group was changed. 

The screen layout for an account group determines which fields are relevant for that group. Suppress/Hidden fields are not displayed in app Manage G/L Account Master for accounts.  It is necessary to change the Account Group back to display fields relevant for prior account group if these fields not relevant for current account group assigned. 

see 3690363 Error raised on G/L Account during posting

entry.title: Question about Data Products with Live Access in SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I‚Äôm working with a Data Product that is based on a live connection (Delivery Mode: Live Access). When a user installs this Data Product in a space, the user receives a view.
However, when the underlying view changes, these changes are not reflected in the installed Data Product.

My question:
Is it possible for a Data Product using Live Access to automatically pick up changes made to the underlying view?
If yes, how can this be achieved?

From what I understand, ‚ÄúEdit Release‚Äù only applies to Data Products using Full Replication, not Live Access.

Any insights would be greatly appreciated, this would really help me.

Thanks and best regards

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud Logging Service (CLS) API access

However based on our initial investigation it requires additional perquisites to be implemented before security standard approves it - which we schedule to work on H2,2026 (validating OIDC/JWT/Cert based auth in addition to just basic auth, user roles management with reduced scope and shared responsibility for effects of using of the APIs)

entry.title: Re: SAP HANA SQLScript: calculate working days between days

entry.title: Re: Manage group to team assignments for SAC within Ident...
entry.content:
Hi @renejurmann 

We have discussed this earlier in the community and I think is much easier to configure the group assignments via SAML this is explained in detail in the learning with some AS Java system, but the idea is the same using CIS. This is much simpler than provisioning the users via IPS.

As a general rule for IPS to avoid overwriting users or assignments we usually have a PATCH operation available as part of the SCIM protocol. If you check in the documentation https://help.sap.com/docs/identity-provisioning/identity-provisioning/target-sap-analytics-cloud you'll see a note refering to the parameter "sac.support.patch.operation" and the exact issue you're facing with role removals.

In terms fo the transformation if the groups only differ beacause of the value "_dev_"  I'd look for just one replace string function to alwas replace "_dev" with "" (empty value)

entry.title: Pattern funtion for RFC
entry.content:
SAP has many functionalities that simplify coders. But We didn't sometimes find a simple requirement. This is one of them. Pattern for RFCs. Here the solution of steps.

All of ABAP coders know and like Patterns. But there is not a simple way to put RFC functions.

Here the solution:

1- Define Custom Pattern 

Follow SE38->Utilities->More Utilities->Edit Pattern  node and define a new one with the name "

 

2- We will create a function in both systems. First below code is for source system which will call target RFC. Function name should start with the name of pattern Z_RFC_FUNCTION and follow EDITOR_EXIT So it's : Z_RFC_FUNCTION_EDITOR_EXIT.

You will see I'm calling a function which will return required source code for RFC call at the line of 31. Of course you should change the DESTINATION with your system rfc. 

FUNCTION z_rfc_function_editor_exit.
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  TABLES
*"      BUFFER TYPE  RSWSOURCET
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
  DATA lt_sval TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF sval.
  DATA ls_sval TYPE sval.

  DATA: buffer2 TYPE rswsourcet.

* Get name of structure from user
  ls_sval-tabname = 'RS38L'.
  ls_sval-fieldname = 'NAME'.
  ls_sval-field_attr  = '00'.
  APPEND ls_sval TO lt_sval.

  CALL FUNCTION 'POPUP_GET_VALUES'
    EXPORTING
      popup_title     = 'Enter Function Name'
    TABLES
      fields          = lt_sval
    EXCEPTIONS
      error_in_fields = 1
      OTHERS          = 2.

* Get the given structure name
  READ TABLE lt_sval INTO ls_sval INDEX 1.
  check ls_sval-value is not INITIAL.

  CALL FUNCTION 'Z_RFC_FUNCTION_EDITOR_EXIT'
    DESTINATION 'KHDCLNT100'
    EXPORTING
      funcname = ls_sval-value
    IMPORTING
      buffer   = buffer2.

  LOOP AT buffer2 INTO DATA(ls_buffer).

    APPEND ls_buffer TO buffer.

  ENDLOOP.
ENDFUNCTION.

3- Second is for target system which RFC will be run. I gave the same name for the function to get the source code from target system. Here it's Z_RFC_FUNCTION_EDITOR_EXIT.

FUNCTION z_rfc_function_editor_exit.
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     VALUE(FUNCNAME) TYPE  RS38L-NAME
*"  EXPORTING
*"     VALUE(BUFFER) TYPE  RSWSOURCET
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------

  DATA: l_pattern_obj TYPE REF TO cl_sedi_pattern_generator,
        l_pattern     TYPE swbse_max_line_tab,
        l_pattern_new TYPE swbse_max_line_tab.

  DATA: lv_line TYPE LINE OF swbse_max_line_tab.

  CREATE OBJECT l_pattern_obj
    EXPORTING
      i_column  = 0
      i_include = CONV #( 'ZTESTYK' ).

  l_pattern_obj->built_function(
             EXPORTING
               i_function_name = CONV #( funcname )
             IMPORTING
               e_pattern       = l_pattern ).
  LOOP AT l_pattern INTO lv_line.

    APPEND lv_line TO l_pattern_new.

    IF lv_line CP 'CALL FUNCTION*'.
      APPEND 'DESTINATION ''KHDCLNT100''' TO l_pattern_new.
    ENDIF.


  ENDLOOP.

  buffer[] = l_pattern_new.

ENDFUNCTION.

And it's coming to test üôÇ

You will simply select other pattern and it will ask function name.

Just put the RFC function name.

Here it comes.

Also i suggest doing the below settings for better editorial.

Cheers ykburda üôÇ

entry.title: Guidance on Global Settlement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud PS
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

We are currently implementing the Project System (PS) module for one of our SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud customers, and we‚Äôve encountered an issue during the global settlement process.

Our scenario starts with creating an investment project using the ‚ÄúProyectos empresariales‚Äù app (scope item 1NT). The project already has actual costs posted to a WBS element, and an investment profile is assigned. This profile automatically creates a settlement rule to an Asset under Construction (AuC) ‚Äî and this part works perfectly.

The settlement to the AuC runs successfully, and the settlement rule is generated automatically as expected.

However, the issue arises when performing the final (global) settlement to the completed fixed asset. The system throws an error message, preventing us from completing the process. We‚Äôve attached a screenshot showing the exact system message.

We would like to understand:

  • What is the root cause of this issue ‚Äî is it related to configuration, process steps, or a standard restriction in SAP S/4HANA Cloud PS?

  • What are the standard steps and prerequisites to perform a successful final settlement to a fixed asset within the SAP Cloud PS standard process?

We have been analyzing this behavior for several days but haven‚Äôt been able to identify a solution. Any insights or guidance from the community would be greatly appreciated.

If any specific details are needed (e.g., Project ID, WBS element, client/mandante), I‚Äôll be glad to provide them.

Thank you in advance for your support and contributions!

Best regards,

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: Re: SAC error "We couldn't connect to your BW system"
entry.content:
Hi there

I was experiencing the exact same issue  with SAC story based on BW live model. Just found out that the problem was related to user settings in BW: somehow the "contractual user type ID" (SU01) was changed and that was the causing the issue. Also a hint, if that is not your exact problem: check authorization data in BW SU53 for the user. And if you ask colleagues to delete Cache, then they might get a pop-up for allowing cloud connection, and it is important to allow this. 

Cheers,

Andr√©

entry.title: Can we connect Actual On Premise DataBase to Cloud ALM (Apart from ABAP system)
entry.content:
We understand that Cloud ALM will be focused for Cloud Systems. 

We have customers that still have on premise Systems, and we have successfully linked them to the Cloud ALM (ABAP instances) and can see some Database metrics under Health Monitoring. 

The question is: Is it possible to link the actual Database to ALM also (apart from the ABAP system), to see even more DB monitoring tools that is beyond the ABAP system health Monitoring and the few monitors we see there?

My understanding is that SAP in Future want all clients in cloud, and then Databases will be monitored by SAP with some inhouse systems and there might not be a need for a client to monitor the DB themselves, but until such time there is clients who might like to see more on-premise Database type monitors.

- Things like "is backups running on DATABASE"

- Has database backups run successfully / or not.

 

(Sorry if using wrong terminology - language thing.)

entry.content:
Hi,
I am setting up packing instruction using reference material. According to documentation, the you need to :
1. Create reference material (in my example ref-pallet1) (VERP) which is maintained on products (WMTG12) which are packed same way as reference material. On material WMTG12 reference mat.for packing is maintained.

 

2. Then packing instruction is created for reference materials ref-pallet1. Row is marked with R.

3. Determination is maintained for 0IBD Inbound delivery

If I now test to pack in WM inbound delivery, it does not create HU automatically. 

If I maintain the determination for WMTG12 by using same packing instruction -> then system is able to pack according to instruction. Is this how it is supposed to work? I understood from SAP documentation that the determination would be maintained only for reference material?

entry.title: Hidden Crisis: Ageing Infrastructure, Reactive O&M, and the Data Problem No One Is Solving
entry.content:
Why ageing infrastructure and reactive maintenance are accelerating into a classic hockey-stick cost curve for oil and gas industry, and how trusted master data is the only realistic path to predictive excellence.

Dr. Imad Syed, CEO, PiLog Group 

 

The oil and gas (O&G) industry remains one of the world‚Äôs most critical sources of primary energy, shaping global economic stability and long-term development. Yet behind this strategic importance lies an accelerating challenge: an ageing infrastructure that is pushing operations and maintenance (O&M) into a reactive, high-cost spiral.

Many upstream and midstream assets ‚Äì platforms, pipelines, processing units and refineries ‚Äì are now 20-30 years old. Science journal, Nature, found that many of the world‚Äôs 12,000 offshore platforms are nearing their end-of-life. More than 3,000 installations in the North Sea and Gulf of Mexico have already exceeded 25-30 years of operation.

Ageing assets drive a predictable but costly pattern: the ‚Äúhockey-stick‚Äù curve of O&M costs. As corrosion, fouling, fatigue, and obsolete parts accumulate, operators are forced into more inspections, more emergency work, more reverse-engineering, and ultimately more unplanned shutdowns. Downtime alone can exceed $1 million per day per asset. Global outages contribute to more than 10 million barrels per day of lost production ‚Äì representing nearly $200 billion in annual revenue foregone.

Our analysis of 18 global publicly listed O&G companies reveals that O&M already represents 18% of their total operating costs, rising to as high as 35% for some players. This cost pressure is magnified whenever price cycles trigger deferred maintenance, compounding future reliability risk.

 

Why Digital Investments Alone Don‚Äôt Solve the Problem

The industry has responded with aggressive investments in digital technologies. Global O&G digital transformation spend reached an estimated $77-90 billion in 2024 and is projected to rise to $90-124 billion in 2025: approximately 10-15% of upstream/downstream CAPEX.

Some leaders, including ExxonMobil, Chevron, and Saudi Aramco report strong returns through reduced downtime and optimized assets. However, scaling remains the industry‚Äôs biggest weakness: only 13-36% of firms have taken successful pilots into full-scale operations. Nearly 60-70% remain stuck in pilot mode.

The root cause is clear:

Digital tools generate data, but most O&G operators lack the foundational master data integrity required to turn that data into reliable decisions.

Sensors proliferate, but only 13% of companies use this data strategically. Legacy systems Maximo, ERP, SCADA, CMMS, engineering repositories, procurement databases hold conflicting records of the same assets, parts, BOMs, locations, and vendors. Without a ‚Äòsingle version of the truth‚Äô, predictive models cannot be trusted, digital twins cannot remain accurate, and planners spend more time reconciling than optimizing.

The result: fragmented data, stalled initiatives, and a widening gap between digital ambition and operational reality.

 

Master Data Management (MDM): The Missing Foundation for O&M Transformation

Master Data Management is not a ‚Äúdata-cleaning exercise‚Äù ‚Äì it is a structural capability that enables oil & gas operators to control the lifecycle, quality, and reliability of asset, equipment, material, and vendor data across all systems. When done properly, it directly addresses both the ageing infrastructure challenge and the industry‚Äôs deeply reactive maintenance culture.

MDM gives operators:

  • A single asset golden record that integrates engineering, EAM, CMMS, inspection, procurement, and sensor data
  • Clean, enriched, audit-ready records of equipment, parts, hierarchies, and BOMs
  • Governance workflows that ensure every change is approved, traceable, and compliant
  • The ability to feed digital twins and AI engines with trusted, high-quality data
  • The foundation required to shift from reactive to predictive maintenance                                                                            
  1. Strengthening Asset Integrity for Ageing Infrastructure

Integrity management depends on reliable equipment history, correct system hierarchies, validated inspection data, and traceable change records. Ageing assets amplify the consequences of poor data ‚Äì small inaccuracies can lead to missed integrity threats and unplanned shutdowns.

MDM provides:

  • A unified master asset record (tag, serial, function, location, BOM, history, specs, certificates)
  • Cleansing and enrichment with OEM data, calibration records, and criticality ratings
  • Governance that ensures every change ‚Äì a modification, retrofit, or decommissioning ‚Äì is documented and approved

The result is an asset register that becomes the single, authoritative source for risk-based integrity planning and regulatory compliance.

  1.  Moving Beyond Reactive Maintenance to Predictive Excellence

Predictive maintenance cannot succeed without clean, consistent, and connected master data. AI/ML models rely on correct sensor-to-asset mapping, harmonized failure codes, and trustworthy historical labels.

MDM enables:

  • Accurate ‚Äúsensor ‚Üí asset ‚Üí system‚Äù mapping
  • High-quality historical maintenance data aligned to standard failure modes
  • Enriched material masters with lead times, alternate parts, and criticality
  • Validated data flows into PdM engines, digital twins, and planning systems

 

Industry estimates indicate that predictive-maintenance excellence made possible by reliable master data can reduce unplanned downtime by 20-30% and cut maintenance costs by 5-15%, rising to 20-30% with advanced AI-based scheduling and spares optimization.

 

  1. Reducing Costs Through Better Materials, Spares, and Inventory Data

Good master data creates quantifiable value:

  • Lower inventory and working-capital costs
  • Fewer emergency purchases
  • Higher first-time fix rates
  • Better compliance and reporting
  • Faster work-order planning and execution

O&G companies frequently carry 10-25% duplicate materials, which directly inflate procurement and storage costs. Clean, standardized material masters eliminate duplication, enforce catalogue discipline, and drive more strategic sourcing.

 

How PiLog‚Äôs DQG Suite Delivers These Outcomes

Together with SAP, PiLog has embarked on a partnership journey to address these industry challenges.  Complementing and enriching SAP Intelligent Asset Management, PiLog‚Äôs Data Quality and Governance (DQG) Suite is built to deliver the exact MDM capabilities required for aging infrastructures, predictive maintenance, and integrated O&M operations.

The suite provides:

  • End-to-end data migration, standardization, cleansing, enrichment, and governance
  • AI-enabled classification based on ISO 81346 and ISO 14224
  • Harmonized assets, equipment, and material records for SAP EAM, APM, and S/4HANA
  • Seamless integration with SAP APM, FSM, IBP (MRO), BNAC, BN4P, and IPD
  • A foundation for digital twins, predictive maintenance, and data-driven operational excellence

Common Pain Points Identified Across PiLog‚Äôs O&G Customers

  • Duplicate or inconsistent material masters
  • Unstructured PR/PO creation and poor service masters
  • Missing or incomplete asset and equipment masters
  • Multi-entity inconsistencies across business groups

Quantifiable Improvements Delivered

  • 10-25% duplicate detection and elimination
  • 10-15% reduction in inventory hoarding
  • 12% YoY reduction in O&M costs
  • 22%+ reduction in sourcing and procurement cost

These results demonstrate that master data is not an IT function, it is an operational performance driver.

 

Aging Assets Are Inevitable ‚Äì Reactive O&M Is Not

The industry cannot stop infrastructure from ageing. But it can change how it responds.

Digital investments alone will not close the reliability gap. A foundational shift to high-quality master data, governed, enriched, standardized, and connected across all systems ‚Äì is what allows O&G companies to control the cost curve, extend asset life, and move decisively toward predictive maintenance excellence.

With the right master data foundations, operators can break the cycle of reactive firefighting and build a more reliable, safer, and economically resilient O&M model.

entry.title: Adding Custom Fields to List Views in SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
In the world of digital tools, one size rarely fits all. We all have different needs and preferences, and being able to tweak and adjust these tools can make all the difference. In SAP Fieldglass, you can customize how you capture information by creating custom fields. And I have good news for you: in some cases, you can add custom fields to your list views as columns. Let's explore how this can transform your experience with SAP Fieldglass. 

 

How can this help you?  

Do you use custom fields in your company? You probably do. While SAP Fieldglass standard fields are comprehensive, every company is unique. If you‚Äôre using custom fields to collect information not available in the standard fields, you might want to add them to the list views for easier visualization. If so, this blog is for you. 

 

How to start

How to add a custom field to a list view: 

  1. Select List Views in the Configuration section 
  2. Select the list you want to add the custom field to  
  3. Select +Add Fields  
  4. Select the custom field you want to add 
    Note: On this screen, you can‚Äôt see a difference between custom and system fields 
  5. Select Add 

 

 

After adding the custom field, you can see that its field type is Custom: 

Be aware that list view types Other Data, PMO Dashboard, and Work Items don‚Äôt display custom fields. Also, custom fields created for a module may be displayed for one list type and not for others. For steps on creating a custom field and the full list of lists that display custom fields by modules, see Custom Fields in List Views. 

 

Now it‚Äôs your turn to add all the custom fields to list views and make your SAP Fieldglass experience even more personalized!

entry.title: System copy for convergent charging
entry.content:
What is convergent charging?

SAP Convergent Charging is a powerful rating and pricing solution designed for high-volume processing in service industries, particularly within the SAP Billing and Revenue Innovation Management (BRIM) ecosystem.

SAP Convergent Charging serves as a critical component that handles the rating and pricing aspects of order-to-cash scenarios. The system processes consumption data through several key steps :

  1. Receiving consumption items from Convergent Mediation as input
  2. Calculating corresponding usage fees for these consumption items
  3. Generating billable items that are loaded into Convergent Invoicing for billing purposes

Assumptions

1. Target convergent charging (CC) environment is already available.

2. Source and Target are on the same versions

3. Database type is same on source and target

Now , lets go through the pre-requisites , restore and post steps of convergent charging system copy.

Pre-requisites

1. Parameter export on source and target

The parameters would be later required for comparison

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<Instance number>/script

 Command - ./config.sh configuration export <directory>/parameters.xml all

2. Jstart parameters of source for all instances

The parameters would be later required for comparison

These are located in /usr/sap/<SID>/CC<Instance name><Instance number>/config.

Filename ‚Äì jstart.config

3. License Export on Target

License on the target would be overwritten. Hence take a backup which would be later restored.

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./setup.sh license export exports/license.txt

4. Instance Map export on Target

Instance map would also be overwritten , this would be later imported in post steps.

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./setup.sh instancemap export exports/instance_map.txt

5. Export Jco destinations on Target

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./setup.sh jcodestination export S/4 exports/jco_s4hana.txt

6. ERP reference system check

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./setup.sh erpreferencesystem getJCoDestination

7. Export target database tables

The following tables should be exported from the target system in order to use them if needed. The export can be used to overwrite the configuration coming with the restore of the source system.

‚Ä¢ LICENSE,

‚Ä¢ VERSION,

‚Ä¢ CONFIGURATION,

‚Ä¢ INSTANCE_CONFIGURATION,

‚Ä¢ INSTANCE_MAP,

‚Ä¢ KEY_STORE,

‚Ä¢ INSTANCE_KEY_STORE,

‚Ä¢ INSTANCE_CERT_STORE,

‚Ä¢ CERT_STORE,

8. Take a backup of target database before restore

9. Get the super user passwords of source 

Restore 

Copy the backup taken on source to target. Restore it on the target database using available database tools

Once the backup is restored , validate the super user passwords on target

Post Steps

1. If the schema of target differs from source , update the schema name and password

Update database user and password in DEFAULT profile and boot config files.

Directory - /sapmnt/<SID>/profile

File ‚Äì DEFAULT.PFL

Update database.login field with new schema name and database.password field with new password

Directory - /sapmnt/<SID>/profile/boot

File ‚Äì boot.config

Update SQLHELPER_LOGIN  field with new schema name and SQLHELPER.PASSWORD field with new password

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/config

File ‚Äì boot.config

Update SQLHELPER_LOGIN  field with new schema name and SQLHELPER.PASSWORD field with new password

2. Reset Admin User credentials

Execute below SQL statements from schema user. Refer SAP note 2699499.

 

DELETE FROM USER_PASSWORD WHERE USER_OID = 1;
DELETE FROM USER_RIGHT WHERE USER_OID = 1;
DELETE FROM HCI_USER WHERE OID = 1;
INSERT INTO HCI_USER (OID, LOGIN_ID, PASSWORD, PASSWORD_CHANGE_DATE,
FAILED_LOGIN_COUNT, LOCKED, IS_HUMAN, CHANGE_PASSWORD)
VALUES (1, 'admin', '6989cd27e1ebb4d8f266d5c09469989f1caae07', CURRENT_DATE, 0, 0, 1, 0);
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'admin');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'useradmin');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'csr');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'marketing');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'bartadmin');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'connectoradmin');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'processmanager');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'remotesupport');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'messagechargingclient');

 

3. Import License

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command ‚Äì ./setup.sh license import exports/license.txt

 

4. Update jcodestination 

 

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command ‚Äì  ./setup.sh jcodestination list

 

As seen from above screenshot , there are 2 destinations defined. These need to be adjusted. First step is to export them locally , edit as per target and import them again.

To export, use below commands

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command ‚Äì   ./setup.sh jcodestination export <ERP_JCO_NAME> <ERP_JCO_NAME>.txt

Adjust the hostname in txt file and import using below command.

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./setup.sh jcodestination import ERP <ERP_JCO_NAME> <ERP_JCO_NAME>.txt

Similarly , repeat for CRM destination as well.

 

5. Parameter update

Compare the parameters from source to target in parameters.xml file and change them. Special care to be taken for SQLHELPER_LOGIN which specifies the schema name and SQLHELPER_PASSWORD for schema password. If the parameters are not updated correctly , system wont start. Once the parameters are updated , use below commands to import them.

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./config.sh configuration import parameters.xml

6. Jstart Files

Compare jstart.config files for all the instances with source and update them.

7. Update instance map

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command ‚Äì  ./setup.sh instancemap import exports/instance_map.txt -clean

8. Finally , start the system with sapcontrol command.

 

Common issues after system copy

1. Bulkloader wont start while starting the system

Check the bulkloader logs in /usr/sap/<SID>/CCB<Instance number>/work/log/. The password or host details might not be updated correctly. Export the jcodestinations and manually update the correct details and import. This should be followed by restart of complete system.

entry.title: High-Volume Data Handling in SAP Integration Suite - Our Journey to 10 Million Records
entry.content:
‚ÄúIn the middle of difficulty lies opportunity.‚Äù ‚Äì Albert Einstein

Handling large-volume data integration is something every integration specialist meets sooner or later. Recently, our team faced one of those ‚Äúopportunities‚Äù‚Äîa requirement to transfer around 10 million records from a source system to a target application using SAP Integration Suite (IS) formerly called as SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI).

At first glance, the mapping requirements were straightforward. But as always, the devil hides in the details: the pagination behavior of the OData V4 adapter, the Integration Suite processing limits, and unforeseen behavioral quirks pushed us through several attempts before landing on a robust solution.

This blog walks through:

  • What approaches we tried
  • Why they failed
  • What finally worked
  • Key learnings for anyone building high-volume integrations on SAP IS

Context: The Scenario

The source system exposed data through an OData V4 service. A key limitation we discovered early on:

  • Pagination is fully server-controlled in OData V4 adapter
  • Even if SAP IS is configured for a custom page size (e.g., 1,000 or 10,000), the adapter always respects the server-side limit
  • Example: If the server page size is 50,000, SAP IS will always retrieve chunks of 50,000 - nothing less

This limitation became the center of the problem.

Approach 1 ‚Äî Standard OData V4 Adapter + Looping Process Call

(Expected to work‚Ä¶ reality had other plans)

How it worked:

  • Used the OData V4 adapter as-is with server-side pagination
  • Used Looping Process Call to iterate through pages

What happened:

  • If the total data was below 50K, everything worked smoothly
  • Above 50K, the iFlow got stuck in Processing
  • No errors
  • No termination
  • Messages remained frozen for days

Example:

  • Server page size ‚Üí 50K
  • Data set = 40K ‚Üí Success
  • Data set = 150K ‚Üí iFlow stalled indefinitely

Lesson: Looping + uncontrolled server pagination = unpredictable behavior.

Approach 2 ‚Äî OData V4 Adapter + Custom Pagination Logic

(Better‚Ä¶ but still not scalable enough)

This time we added:

  • Custom counter checks
  • Pagination logic in iFlow
  • Looping until full completion

Result:

  • Worked better than Approach 1
  • Successfully processed volumes under ~1 million records
  • Beyond that threshold ‚Üí iFlow stuck again, still showing Processing but not progressing
  • No runtime error, no bottleneck in MPL ‚Äî simply a silent stall

Lesson: The bottleneck was structural, not logical.

Approach 3 ‚Äî Final Working Solution (and the hero of the story)

‚ÄúSimplicity is the ultimate sophistication.‚Äù ‚Äî Leonardo da Vinci

Key idea:

Avoid OData V4 adapter entirely.

Use the Classic HTTP Adapter with explicit control over pagination (via top & skip).

This allowed us to fully control the data fetch size and execution flow.

Our Winning Architecture

Flow 1: Master Controller iFlow

  1. Call the source system via HTTP adapter
  2. Retrieve total record count
  3. Calculate the required number of batches
    • Batch size = server-side max (e.g., 50K)
  4. For each batch, create a message containing only the skip value
  5. Store skip values in Data Store

Example:

Total records = 1,000,000
Batch size = 50,000
Total batches = 20
Stored skip values = 0, 50000, 100000, ...


Flow 2: Worker iFlow

  1. Poll Data Store
  2. Read skip value
  3. Call API using HTTP adapter with parameters:
    $top=50000
    $skip=<value from datastore>
  4. Process the dataset
  5. Deliver to target system

The Big Win

This mechanism:

  • Gave us full control over pagination
  • Completely bypassed OData V4 limitations
  • Handled 10+ MILLION records without stalls
  • Achieved stable throughput
  • No permanent IFlow ‚ÄúProcessing‚Äù states
  • No invisible bottlenecks

Lesson: If the adapter limits you, take control with HTTP.

Key Learnings

  • SAP Integration Suite is powerful and evolving, but very high-volume scenarios still expose adapter-level limitations
  • OData V4 Adapter may not be suitable for massive pagination-driven extractions in all cases
  • HTTP adapter with custom pagination is a reliable fallback
  • Sometimes the ‚Äúclassic‚Äù tool is the best tool

And yes‚Äîraising an SAP incident might eventually clarify the root cause, but business timelines forced us to engineer a workaround.

Conclusion

High-volume data integration is never trivial. The key is to experiment, observe system behavior, and design around limitations. Our final approach was not just functional‚Äîit was scalable, predictable, and production-proof.

If you‚Äôre dealing with similar large dataset transfers in SAP IS, this solution pattern might save you hours of troubleshooting.

Feedback Welcome

I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts, improvements, or other patterns you‚Äôve successfully used for large-volume integration scenarios in SAP Integration Suite.

Thank you for reading!

I2Integration Solutions | A Startup

entry.title: Re: Packing instruction and determination by using refere...
entry.content:
Dear @ST24,

Yes in Public Cloud it‚Äôs normal that 0IBD packing instruction determination is evaluated on the delivery item product plus supplier/warehouse so a determination record maintained only for your reference material (ref-pallet1) will not be hit for an inbound delivery item whose product is WMTG12.

  • In the 3BR (Warehouse Inbound Processing) best-practice script, SAP explicitly notes that for 0IBD determination you can use only: Warehouse Number, Supplier, Material. That means there‚Äôs no standard key for reference material for packing in the delivered 0IBD determination in this scope/item
  • So the system will only find the packing instruction if you maintain a determination record with Material = WMTG12 (referencing the packing instruction you created on ref-pallet1). That‚Äôs exactly what you observed

 

  • The reference material for packing setup is mainly to reuse the same packing instruction master data across many products so you don‚Äôt create many packing instructions, but you still need determination records per product if your 0IBD condition access is product-based as in the standard cloud best practice
  • Some SAP docs/screens show reference material for packing as a possible field in determination records in general but your specific 0IBD setup in Public Cloud is effectively constrained to the product-based keys

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/d5699934e7004d048c4801b552f3b013/fdae694b57b24c568e284e43a88d76d1.html

Summary:

  • Keep one packing instruction built on ref-pallet1
  • Maintain packing instruction determination for each product like WMTG12, all pointing to that same packing instruction. This is the expected/working approach per the cloud best-practice flow

Best Regards,

Dawid
